item.title: Delete a Cloudformation stack having Lambdas in a VPC quickly
item.description:
If you‚Äôve a Cloudformation stack that creates 1 or more Lambdas in a VPC, you may have noticed that Cloudformation takes a lot of time to delete its Lambda resources. This is so because AWS requires can require upwards of 45 minutes to delete a Lambda‚Äôs Elastic Network Interface (ENI) https://repost.aws/knowledge-center/lambda-delete-cloudformation-stack

This large delay can often be frustrating for a developer, especially when deleting 1 or more Cloudformation stacks having Lambda resources. The the easiest way to resolve this is to just not start Lambdas in a VPC (atleast while a feature in development). However, your employer‚Äôs legal/security guidelines may disallow that. item.title: Update an attribute in all Dynamo items parallely. A practical use case for the Producer Consumer pattern.
item.description:
As a developer who contributes to applications using Dynamo, I often find myself in a situation where I‚Äôve to update an attribute or add an attribute to existing Dynamo items (i.e. backfilling) in 1 or more Dynamo partitions. These partitions typically have millions of items and since Dynamo can update atmost 100 items at once, it can be very time consuming (many hours) to backfill an attribute.

Fortunately, there an relatively easy way to alleviate this problem. Inspired by the Producer Consumer pattern, the Typescript script below iterates through every given partition key and creates many readers and writers to update Dynamo items in parallel.

item.title: Recognize digits with a simple CNN (Convolutional Neural Network) - Draft
item.description:
In my previous blog post, I created a simple Neural Network that can recognize the digit in a given image. In this blog post, let‚Äôs try solving the same problem using a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), which is a Neural Network that‚Äôs particularly powerful for image recognition.

A Convolution is a simple mathematical operation that changes the modifies the value of a pixel by considering the values of surrounding pixels (or more accurately, modifies the value of a pixel by using a weighted sum of values of its surrounding pixels). When an appropriate Convolution is applied to every pixel is an image, it can highlight important aspects of an image (like edges, corners etc.) which can help a Neural Network to more accurately classify the image. This Youtube video illustrates a Convolution operation superbly https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KuXjwB4LzSA&t=512s

item.title: Prevent Chrome from displaying API Response JSON when a user presses the Back¬†button
item.description: Sometime ago, we ran into a bug where Google Chrome displayed an API response JSON instead of HTML when a user pressed the Chrome‚Äôs Back button to navigate back to the previous page. Since this caused our customers to consider our app to be unpolished/dysfunctional, we decided to resolve the bug immediately. Examining the Network panel, we found that when a user pressed the back button, Chrome rendered the previous page from its cache In our app, HTML pages and API requests have the same URLs. When a customer visits the /emails URL in their browser, the server responds with HTML. The page‚Äôs JavaScript then hits the /emails API endpoint to retrieve the user‚Äôs emails. When a customer clicked on any link on the page and then navigated back by pressing the Back button, Chrome displayed the API response JSON of the /emails API endpoint. We found this was because the /emails URL responded with JSON the last time Chrome sent a request to that URL. After googling a bit, we learnt that Chrome‚Äôs caches a page using just the URL and the request method (GET, POST etc.) but not the Accept: application/json header (which is sent for an API request but not a HTML request). A straightforward way to resolve this problem was to simply change our API request URLs slightly and we did just that. We modified the page‚Äôs JavaScript to add a is_api_request=true query param to all API endpoints changing the URL of all our API endpoints.

Modify the migration to something like

  def up
    execute <<-SQL
ALTER TABLE accounts ADD COLUMN enabled_features character varying(255)[] DEFAULT '{}';
